instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board suddenly stuck in S5 state
threads.message:
Board initially showed water damage near the SMC, requiring replacement of several resistors and L5001. The board then started up reliably and worked for several days (notably without any Thunderbolt functionality). Now the board is stuck in S5, with missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> signals.

Ordinarily I would suspect a dead PCH/CPU, but since this board has worked fine until recently, I’m suspicious. Anything I can check before assuming that the PCH just decided to die?

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board suddenly stuck in S5 state
threads.message: Reball SMC as first step for corrosion on its area...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board suddenly stuck in S5 state
threads.message: I’m not currently set up for reballing, but I’ll try heating the SMC with flux.
